newsitem.title: JAPAN: Asia Yemen crude buyers ready to drop Q4 contract.
newsitem.headline: Asia Yemen crude buyers ready to drop Q4 contract.

text.p: Term lifters of Yemen's Masila crude in Japan and South Korea said on Wednesday they were prepared to terminate fourth-quarter contracts if prices were not lowered.
"We will continue to press for lower prices," one term-lifter said. "If Yemen does not cut prices from the third quarter, we will do without Yemeni crude," he said.
Most other Asian term-buyers said they would also drop fourth-quarter contracts if prices were not lowered.
On Wednesday, Yemen said it had rolled over its official fourth-quarter Masila crude oil price to maintain it at dated Brent minus 45 cents.
The price of Marib Light crude for the fourth quarter was also rolled over at dated Brent flat, Yemen's Supreme Council for Economy and Oil Affairs said in a statement.
Buyers said they wanted Masila to be lowered to a price ranging between dated Brent minus 55 cents to minus 65 cents.
"Even with Masila priced at dated Brent minus 55 cents, the economics are not good," a trader said. "We are not afraid of terminating our contract," he said.
Traders said they may choose to revive contracts for the first-quarter of 1997 depending on prices.
The most recent sales of Masila crude in the spot market have been at steep discounts of up to 15 cents to the official selling price.
Traders said Masila crude is difficult to sell in Asia because the price is linked to Brent and not crudes such as Oman and Dubai, which are regarded as benchmarks in Asia.
Brent-linked crudes lose price competitiveness in Asia when the price of Brent rises in comparison to Oman and Dubai.
